result.execSummary:
The defendant Randy G. Thompson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Repeater, Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation now serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  If the defendant is placed on probation or released to extended supervision, IT IS ORDERED that the defendant pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.
Obtain and maintain employment, commensurate with his mental health and treatment needs.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Defendant to be subject to random alcohol and drug testing by his agent.

No physical discipline of minor children.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

Continue with mental health treatment and recommendations of his treatment providers.

Amended 2/15/17:  Jail credit of 6 days is granted.

supervisions.notes: A civil judgment has been entered against you for the unpaid Court ordered financial obligations on this case.

records.addlTxt:
SEHR on 15CF205 & 16CF258:

Defendant appears in person in custody with counsel SPD Travis Satorius.  Gerald Fox appears for the State.  DA Fox addresses one item in the revocation summary regarding 15CF205 that he should get 6 days sentence credit on that case.  Defense counsel in is agreement.  Court notes that it's already noted on the amended JOC in narrative but not noted at bottom of AJOC.  No other changes or corrections noted.  

DA Fox recommends on 15CF205 - 6 to 9 months jail; 16CF258 - agrees with DOC recommendation of 6 months but with sentence to run consecutive.  15CF205 is a victim case but the State has not received any response.  Discussion regarding his mental health issue that was brought up in February in 16CF258 to make SPD Satorius aware of this.  SPD Satorius believes the agent's recommendation is appropriate and makes statement to the Court.  Defendant exercises his right to allocution and makes a statement to the Court.

Court orders on 15CF205 a jail sentence of 6 months jail; 16CF258 orders a 6 month jail sentence concurrent to 15CF205.  Sentence credit granted of 62 days on 16CF258; 15CF205 credit granted of 70 days of jail credit.  Civil judgment for unpaid costs.
Sentencing hearing on revocation on May 3, 2017 at 09:00 am.
and revocation summary
from DOC
Received a handwritten note dated 2/15/17 from Judge Becker on an email the J.A. sent to the DA.  She is granting the requested jail credit 6 days jail credit and the JOC should be amended.
destroyed
DNA Proof of Submission form
From attorney Araysa Simpson to Judge regarding sentence credit.  (sent hard copy to Judge to review)

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person and with Attorney Simpson. Victim notification complied with.  Defendant plead guilty to count 3, DC domestic repeater.  Remaining counts dismissed but read in for sentencing purposes  15CF201 dismissed outright.  Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the count he plead to.  Defendant understood.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Repeater allegation confirmed by the court.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.  Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his pleas and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of Disorderly Conduct, domestic, as a repeater, contrary to 947.01(1), 968.075(1)(a), 939.62(1)(a).  Joint recommendation for: 1 year probation.  DNA sample and surcharge.  Obtain and maintain employment.  Continue with mental health treatment.  The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Court ordered:  sentence withheld,  1 year probation.  DNA sample and surcharge.  Obtain and maintain employment commensurate with his mental health and treatment needs.  Continue with mental health treatment and recommendations from his treatment providers.  The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.  Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located. CC.  No physicial discipline of minor children.  Subject to random alcohol and drug testing.
